results.title: The Birders
results.creator_credit: David Morgan, John Richardson, Broken Hill Proprietary Company and Kestrel Films (Australia)
results.brief_description: Winner of the 1976 Australian National Travel Association Jedda Award at the Australian Film Awards. The mutton bird industry of the Furneaux Islands (Cape Barren Island and Flinders Island) in Bass Strait is a little known and historic primary industry started by sealers more than 150 years ago. The film records the rugged life style of the small band of people involved in Mutton birding. Narrated by Ross Thompson and photographed by Kevin Anderson. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: The Bird who is a clown
results.creator_credit: John Walker and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Introduces the island Daphne Major of the Galapagos Islands which is a small island and nesting ground for hundrreds of Blue-footed Booby birds. Emphasises the mating and upbringing of the young in order to illustrate the development of the Booby and to reveal its behaviour patterns. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: The Biosphere
results.creator_credit: William Pettigrew, Barrie Howells, Colin Low, Peter Katadotis and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The McKenzie and Amazon Valleys are 10,000 kilometres distant from one another and are certainly distinct ecologically. Yet in a subtle sense they are collaborating elements within the biosphere - the Earth’s thin layer of living matter. This film examines two of the myriad river ecosystems and shows how they are linked within the biosphere.

results.title: The Big snit
results.creator_credit: Richard Condie and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This wonderfully wacky animated film looks at two simultaneous conflicts, the macrocosm of global nuclear war and the microcosm of a domestic quarrel, and how each conflict is resolved. Presented with warmth and unexpectedly off-the-wall humour, the film is open to a multitude of interpretations. (Awards: Montreal, Toronto, Chicago, San Francisco, Annecy, Hiroshima, Cracow, Zagreb, Tampere)

results.title: The Big picture: conservation treatment of a large painting
results.creator_credit: Ian Hart, Canberra. College of Advanced Education. Media Centre and Department of Home Affairs
results.brief_description: Conservators, Allan Byrne and Tom Dixon, discuss the restoration of the huge oil paint by Tom Roberts entitled “The Opening of the First Parliament of the Australian Commonwealth by His Majesty King George V (when Duke of York). 9th May 1901”. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels and tertiary/teacher level.

results.title: The Big one
results.creator_credit: Michael Moore, Kathleen Glynn, BBC, Dog Eat Dog Films, Mayfair Entertainment International and Miramax Films
results.brief_description: Written and directed by Michael Moore, this is a documentary account of Moore travelling across America to promote his most recent book “Downsize this: random threats from an unarmed American”. Moore, unbeknown to the book’s publishers, gathers a film crew to follow him as he gives public lectures, signs books and gives surprise visits to large corporations. Moore challenges some executives at large companies asking why they are ‘downsizing’ staff in a time of record profits. He visits not only large cities but also some small towns - including one town that was listed as the worst in America. He talks to workers and townsfolk who are trying to live on minimum wage and those who have not had pay increases in many, many years. Large factories are closing down across America as companies use cheaper overseas labour in their manufacturing processes. Only one CEO agrees to an interview, the head of Nike, and he does not provide Michael with a happy ending to his film - Nike shoes are not manufactured in America and are made by teenage workers in Indonesia (minimum age of 14) - something the CEO has no problem with. Using his unique mix of humour, compassion and outright brashness, Moore has created a glimpse into the social and political climate in America in the late 1990s.

results.title: The Big dig
results.creator_credit: Marje Aleck and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Follows a team of archaeologists and students working on the Gezer archaeological expedition as they explore the remains of the city of Gezer in ancient Philistia, now in Israel. Suitable for secondary years 7-12.
